entry.et: Middle English saisen, from Anglo-French seisir, from Medieval Latin sacire, of Germanic origin; perhaps akin to Old High German sezzen to set set

def.dt: :to vest ownership of a freehold estate in
:to put in possession of something the biographer will be seized of all pertinent papers
:to take possession of by legal process
:to attack or overwhelm physically :afflict seized with chest pains
:to possess (as one's mind) completely or overwhelmingly seized the popular imagination Basil Davenport
:to bind or fasten together with a lashing of small stuff (as yarn, marline, or fine wire)
:to take or lay hold suddenly or forcibly
:to cohere to a relatively moving part through excessive pressure, temperature, or friction used especially of machine parts (as bearings, brakes, or pistons)
:to fail to operate due to the seizing of a part used of an engine
:of, relating to, or characteristic of the architecture or furniture of the reign of Louis XVI of France
